importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: China expanded export controls on 12 out of 17 rare-earth metals and certain refining equipment, effective December 1, in response to US trade restrictions.
Trump announced a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, effective from November 1, and imposed export controls on critical software, escalating tensions ahead of the US-China meeting.
Trump and Xi are scheduled to meet in South Korea during the APEC summit, making this date critical for diplomatic negotiations and potential de-escalation.
Former President Joe Biden implemented stricter controls on US semiconductor exports to China, restricting access to advanced chip-making tools and equipment.
Biden restricted US exports of advanced computer chips to China, targeting AI and military technologies to limit China’s technological advancement.
Biden introduced export controls on semiconductors and semiconductor manufacturing tools, restricting China’s access to advanced chip-making technology.
The US Bureau of Industry and Security enforced new rules to block Huawei from using US technology to design semiconductors globally, disrupting Chinese tech supply chains.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2018 to 2024 marks the sustained escalation of US-China trade tensions, including multiple rounds of tariffs and export controls, culminating in the 100% tariff threat in 2025.
This period reflects the current phase of strategic competition, including rare earth export restrictions and high-tariff threats, signaling a potential resumption of trade war dynamics.

keyTakeAways: The US and China are engaged in a high-stakes trade and technology rivalry, with both nations using economic and export controls as strategic tools.

China’s export controls on rare earth minerals—critical for electric vehicles, smartphones, and military tech—are justified under national security concerns and appear to be a pre-emptive move ahead of the US-China summit.
Trump’s threat of a 100% tariff on Chinese goods is unprecedented and could reignite a trade war, even though earlier tariffs were reduced to 30% in 2024.

The US has a long history of imposing tariffs on Chinese goods, beginning with the 2018 25% tariff, and escalating to 145% in some cases, while China has responded with reciprocal tariffs and export bans.
Both nations are weaponizing economic interdependence, with China expanding its 'comprehensive national security' framework and the US targeting military-linked Chinese firms and technologies.
The US claims to act in national security interest, but China accuses it of double standards and discriminatory practices, particularly in targeting Chinese firms in tech and defense sectors.
Experts suggest that although China is more strategic and prepared, the US holds greater economic leverage due to its global market size and domestic consumer base.
The upcoming meeting in South Korea could serve as a critical moment for de-escalation, but the threat of escalation remains high due to each side’s use of 'leverage' and 'reciprocal' measures.
Market stability and global economic conditions will determine whether the trade conflict is resolved diplomatically or escalates further.
Both nations are signaling resolve through calibrated threats, with China using slow, phased export controls and the US using dramatic tariff announcements to project strength.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article details the escalating trade tensions between the United States and China, centered on a 100% tariff threat by US President Donald Trump in response to China’s export controls on rare earth minerals. China justifies its actions as a defense of national security, claiming the US has engaged in discriminatory trade restrictions. The US has a long history of imposing tariffs and export controls on Chinese goods, from 2018 to 2025, including a 100% tariff announced in October 2025. China’s restrictions on rare earths—critical for technology and defense—target US reliance on Chinese supply chains. Experts highlight that both nations are leveraging economic and technological tools, with China appearing more strategic and prepared, while the US has broader economic resilience. The upcoming meeting between Trump and Xi in South Korea is seen as a potential turning point, but the threat of escalation persists, with both sides maintaining a posture of strength and readiness to use retaliatory measures. The situation underscores a deepening rivalry where trade, technology, and national security are increasingly intertwined.
title: Trump’s 100% tariff threat: History of US trade measures against China
